commander.name: Generalleutnant Ludwig Crüwell
commander.previous_service: Commander XXXXVII. Panzerkorps (Poland 1939), Commander XXXXI. Panzerkorps (France 1940, Barbarossa 1941)
commander.notes: Promoted to General der Panzertruppe on 1 February 1942. Commanded DAK Sept 1941 - May 1942 when captured. Replaced Rommel when latter promoted to Panzergruppe Afrika command. Captured 29 May 1942 when Fieseler Storch shot down by South African forces.

chief_of_staff.name: Oberstleutnant Fritz Bayerlein
chief_of_staff.notes: Previously Ia (operations officer) of 15. Panzer-Division. Promoted to Oberst 1 March 1942. Later became Chief of Staff Panzerarmee Afrika (1 June 1942) after Gause wounded.

command.headquarters_location: Mobile HQ, Cyrenaica (Libya) - Q1 1942: Mersa el Brega (Jan), Agedabia (late Jan), Benghazi (Feb-Mar)
command.parent_command: Panzerarmee Afrika (Rommel) - redesignated from Panzergruppe Afrika on 30 January 1942

Panzer III Ausf J.notes: New long-barreled variant arriving Q4 1941/Q1 1942 - superior penetration vs British Crusader/Grant. Primary medium tank 21. Panzer.

Panzer IV Ausf F1.notes: 21. Panzer-Division, improved armor over Ausf E. Close support.

Panzer II Ausf C.notes: Reconnaissance tanks (20 from 15. Pz, 18 from 21. Pz). Many lost in Operation Crusader Nov-Dec 1941.

Panzer I Ausf B.notes: Training/liaison only (5 from 15. Pz, 3 from 21. Pz). Most lost Q4 1941.

SdKfz 251.notes: 60 from 15. Pz, 55 from 21. Pz. Many casualties in Operation Crusader.

Opel Blitz 3-ton.notes: Standard Wehrmacht truck (600 from 15. Pz, 485 from 21. Pz). Heavy attrition from Operation Crusader and long supply hauls.

Mercedes-Benz L3000.notes: Heavy transport (390 from 15. Pz, 350 from 21. Pz)

Büssing-NAG.notes: Artillery tractor (210 from 15. Pz, 215 from 21. Pz)

Krupp L2H143.notes: Light cargo (150 from 15. Pz, 165 from 21. Pz)

Horch Kfz.15.notes: Staff cars (90 from 21. Pz, 5 corps HQ)

Recovery vehicles.notes: 38 from 15. Pz, 10 corps pool. Critical for tank repairs after Crusader.

Fuel tankers.notes: 125 from 15. Pz, 18 from 21. Pz, 12 corps pool. Many lost to British air/naval interdiction.

Water tankers.notes: 105 from 15. Pz, 13 corps pool, 10 from various

Workshop vehicles.notes: 80 from 15. Pz, 22 from 21. Pz, 13 corps pool. Worked overtime restoring tanks post-Crusader.

Ambulances.notes: 60 from 15. Pz, 12 from 21. Pz, 10 corps medical

Staff cars.notes: 26 from 15. Pz (also listed in trucks category)

5cm PaK 38.notes: Primary AT gun (22 from 15. Pz, 16 from 21. Pz)

3.7cm PaK 35/36.notes: Light AT gun, obsolete vs British Matilda II (16 from 15. Pz, 10 from 21. Pz)

8.8cm FlaK 18/36.notes: Dual-purpose AA/AT (10 from 15. Pz, 8 from 21. Pz). Highly effective in anti-tank role - decisive vs British cruiser tanks. 2 lost in Crusader.

2cm FlaK 38.notes: Improved light AA (8 from 15. Pz, 22 from 21. Pz)

fighters.note: Luftwaffe support provided at theater level by Fliegerführer Afrika (not organic to DAK)

reconnaissance.note: Fieseler Fi 156 Storch aircraft used for liaison by Rommel/Crüwell, not counted in corps TO&E

supply_logistics.supply_status: CRITICAL - Post-Operation Crusader depletion. Extended supply lines from Tripoli (800-1000+ km) via single coastal road (Via Balbia). British naval interdiction (Malta-based RAF/RN) destroys 30-40% of Axis convoys. Fuel reserves 5-6 days (lowest of war so far), ammunition 8-9 days, water 10-15L/man/day (critical desert constraint), food 10-12 days. Rommel Papers document: 'Only 18,000 tons reached Panzer Army in March 1942 out of 60,000 ton requirement.' Supply convoy arrived 5 Jan 1942 (55 tanks, 20 armored cars, AT guns) enabled Jan counter-offensive. Supply base: Tripoli port (sole Axis lifeline). Forward supply dumps at Mersa el Brega (Jan), Benghazi recaptured 29 Jan (critical port). Q1 1942: Rebuilding phase after Crusader losses.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal desert (Cyrenaica/Tripolitania) - sand, gravel, rocky escarpments, wadis, minimal vegetation, no water sources. Q1 1942 operations: Mersa el Brega → Agedabia → Benghazi → Gazala Line defensive positions.

subordinate_units.composition: Panzer-Regiment 8, Schützen-Regimenter 104/115, Kradschützen-Bataillon 15, Artillerie-Regiment 33, support units
subordinate_units.equipment_summary: 86 tanks (71 medium, 15 light), 68 field artillery, 38 AT guns, 2485 vehicles
subordinate_units.notes: Post-Crusader rebuild. Von Vaerst commanded from 1 Jan 1942 (replaced Neumann-Silkow KIA 9 Dec 1941). Tank strength reduced from 155 (Q2 1941) to 86 (Q1 1942) - 45% loss in Crusader.

subordinate_units.composition: Panzer-Regiment 5, Panzergrenadier-Regimenter 104/155, Aufklärungs-Abteilung 3, Artillerie-Regiment 155, support units
subordinate_units.equipment_summary: 79 tanks (48 medium, 31 light), 32 field artillery, 26 AT guns, 2095 vehicles
subordinate_units.notes: Redesignated from 5. leichte Division on 1 August 1941. Von Bismarck commanded from 1 Jan 1942 (replaced von Ravenstein captured 29 Nov 1941). Tank strength reduced from 85 (Q2 1941) to 79 (Q1 1942) - Crusader losses.

subordinate_units.equipment_summary: Radio trucks, telephone equipment, telegraph, motorcycles
subordinate_units.notes: Only organic corps troop unit documented in Tessin Band 14. Essential for coordination of mobile operations in Q1 counter-offensive.

tactical_doctrine.role: German armored corps in North Africa. Mobile armored exploitation force for offensive operations, breakthrough warfare, rapid maneuver in desert terrain. Combined arms coordination at corps level between panzer divisions, motorized infantry, and supporting arms. Q1 1942: Rebuilding after Operation Crusader (Nov-Dec 1941) then launching surprise counter-offensive (21 Jan - 6 Feb 1942) to retake Cyrenaica.
special_capabilities: Rapid exploitation of breakthroughs via two panzer divisions
Mobile defensive operations using 8.8cm FlaK in AT role
Combined arms coordination (tanks, motorized infantry, artillery, AT, AA)
Battlefield improvisation (capture and use of British supplies)
Surprise offensive operations (Jan 1942 counter-offensive caught British off-guard)
tactical_innovations: Revolutionary use of 8.8cm FlaK guns in anti-tank role (devastating vs British cruiser/infantry tanks)
Mobile AT gun screens (PaK 38, 8.8cm FlaK) to lure British armor into kill zones
Rapid desert exploitation using sun compass/dead reckoning navigation
Aggressive use of reconnaissance to find flanks
Capture and immediate use of British fuel/supply dumps (critical in Q1 1942 counter-offensive)
Concentration of armor at decisive points (Schwerpunkt doctrine)
Mobile workshops for rapid battlefield repairs (essential post-Crusader)
Deception operations (Rommel kept Jan 1942 offensive secret from Italian High Command to prevent leaks)
known_issues: Insufficient tank numbers vs British armored forces (165 tanks, down from 240 in Q2 1941 - 31% reduction)
Extended supply lines (800-1000+ km from Tripoli) via single coastal road
British naval/air interdiction destroys 30-40% of Axis supply convoys
Desert conditions: extreme heat, sand (vehicle breakdowns), water scarcity (10-15L/man/day essential)
3.7cm PaK 35/36 inadequate against Matilda II infantry tanks (78mm frontal armor)
Limited spare parts (vehicles/tanks cannibalized for parts)
Vulnerability of soft-skinned vehicles to British air attacks
Chronic fuel shortages (5-6 days reserves, lowest of war - limits operational tempo)
Italian forces require German stiffening (morale/training issues)
No organic air support (dependent on Fliegerführer Afrika at theater level)
Post-Crusader attrition: Tank strength 165 (Q1) vs 240 (Q2 1941), truck operational readiness 80% (Q1) vs 91% (Q2 1941)
British air superiority growing (Malta-based RAF raids on supply convoys)
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Tropical uniforms (khaki), sand filters on all vehicles, desert tires, increased water capacity (tankers), sun compass/dead reckoning navigation, vehicle recovery emphasis (limited replacements), water discipline (10-15L/man/day), capture of British supply dumps essential, mobile workshops for field repairs, aggressive reconnaissance (water sources, supply dumps, enemy positions). Q1 1942: Emphasis on rapid repairs to restore tank strength after Crusader losses.

scenario_suitability: Rommel's Counter-Offensive (21 January - 6 February 1942) - DAK's surprise attack from Mersa el Brega
Battle of Agedabia (22-23 January 1942) - British 1st Armoured Division loses 117 tanks
Capture of Benghazi (28-29 January 1942) - DAK seizes key port and supply dumps
Advance to Gazala Line (February 1942) - DAK establishes defensive positions
Desert patrol actions and reconnaissance battles (Jan-Mar 1942)
Anti-tank ambush scenarios (8.8cm FlaK vs British Crusader/Grant tanks)
Supply convoy interdiction scenarios (British vs Axis convoys)
special_rules: Crüwell leadership bonus: +1 to DAK units within 5km of Crüwell's HQ (less than Rommel's +1 bonus)
8.8cm FlaK guns may fire in AT role (exceptional vs all British armor)
Superior combined arms coordination: +1 to coordination checks
Desert warfare experience: +1 to navigation/survival checks
Extended supply lines penalty: -2 to sustained operations after 4 days without resupply (worse than Q2 1941 due to fuel crisis)
Panzer III J long 50mm gun effective against British Crusader/Grant tanks
British Matilda II infantry tanks immune to 3.7cm PaK (require 5cm PaK or 8.8cm FlaK)
Capture British supply dumps: +3 days fuel/ammunition if British supply dump overrun (critical in Q1 1942)
Post-Crusader attrition: -1 to tank availability checks (tank strength 165 vs 240 in Q2 1941)
Surprise offensive: +2 to initiative rolls for first 2 turns (Jan 1942 counter-offensive caught British off-guard)
historical_engagements: Rommel's Counter-Offensive (21 January - 6 February 1942) - Recaptured Cyrenaica in 2 weeks
Battle of Agedabia (22 January 1942) - British withdraw in disorder, DAK captures town
Envelopment of British 1st Armoured Division (23 January 1942) - 117 British tanks destroyed, 33 guns captured
Pursuit to Msus (24 January 1942) - 98 British armored vehicles destroyed, 38 guns captured
Capture of Benghazi (28-29 January 1942) - Key port and vast supply dumps seized
Advance to Gazala Line (February 1942) - DAK establishes defensive positions
Gazala Line stalemate (February-May 1942) - Both sides build up for summer offensive

source: Tessin Band 14 - Deutsches Afrikakorps organizational structure (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
The Rommel Papers - PRIMARY SOURCE: Tank strength 20 Jan 1942: 111 serviceable at front + 28 in rear = 139 operational (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
The Rommel Papers - Counter-offensive dates, operations, Crüwell command (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
The Rommel Papers - Supply crisis: 'Only 18,000 tons reached Panzer Army in March 1942 out of 60,000 ton requirement' (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
The Rommel Papers - 5 Jan 1942 convoy: 55 tanks, 20 armored cars arrived Tripoli (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
The Rommel Papers - Panzergruppe Afrika redesignated Panzerarmee Afrika on 22 Jan 1942 (Tier 1, 95% confidence)
Nafziger Collection - German OOB North Africa 1942 Q1 (Tier 1, 82% confidence)
Feldgrau.com - DAK unit history, Crüwell command 1 Sept 1941 - 29 May 1942 (Tier 2, 80% confidence)
Cross-referenced: Crüwell commanding 1 Sept 1941 - 29 May 1942 (Tessin, Keilig, Mitcham)
Cross-referenced: Chief of Staff Bayerlein - Rommel Papers, Mitcham
Cross-referenced: Subordinate divisions (15. Pz, 21. Pz) - all sources agree
Calculated: Tank totals (165) from Rommel Papers Q1 1942 data (139 operational + 26 in repair)
Calculated: Personnel (23,850) from division aggregation post-Crusader losses
Calculated: Supply/logistics from Rommel Papers Q1 1942 entries (Jan counter-offensive, March supply crisis)
